Expectation1: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation1: The mandatory daily pre-work safety briefing is starting in two minutes.
Expectation2: Educate the public and the community about their cause.
Situation2: A major news network has just called for an immediate on-air comment to counter misinformation in a breaking story.
Story: I wipe the sweat from my brow as the foreman’s voice crackles over the loudspeaker, calling everyone to the daily safety briefing. My boots are caked with dust, and I know if I’m late, the whole crew will notice. We’re supposed to be a team, and the rules are clear: no one skips the briefing, not even for a minute. But just as I’m about to join the circle, my phone buzzes in my pocket. It’s the news network—live, right now, they need me to speak out, to set the record straight about our cause before the misinformation spreads any further. My heart pounds. The crew expects me to be present, focused, reliable. But my fellow activists are counting on me to be the voice we need in this moment. I can’t be in two places at once. My hands tremble as I stare at the phone, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in, each demanding all of me, right now.
